title: Fasting and Metabolic Illness
content: Utilizing an individualized approach to fasting to successfully treat thousands of overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients. Being a doctor who specializes in kidney disease gives a unique insight into early indications of metabolic disease.

title: Insulin Resistance and Hyperinsulinemia
content: A great discussion on insulin resistance where the case is made that we should actually think of hyperinsulinemia as the underlying problem. Hyperinsulinemia (not insulin resistance) drives metabolic syndrome.

title: Type 2 Diabetes and Treatments
content: The common treatments for type 2 diabetes seem to make things worse. The two step process of developing type 2 diabetes and how they are both manifestations of hyperinsulinemia.

title: Obesity and Inflammation
content: Is obesity causing insulin resistance or is it the other way around? What role does inflammation play in obesity?

title: Fasting and Health
content: Using fasting to empty the cells of glucose. Comparing bariatric surgery to fasting as a treatment for type 2 diabetes. Time-restricted feeding and intermittent fasting: Defining terms, and how they can be applied in practice.

title: Fasting and Muscle Loss
content: Muscle loss during fasting, and why it isn’t a concern. Will fasting help a healthy person live longer? Does fasting cause gallstones?

title: Individualized approach to fasting for overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients
content: Experiences utilizing an individualized approach to fasting to successfully treat thousands of overweight, metabolically ill, and diabetic patients. The difference between time-restricted feeding, intermittent fasting, and dietary restriction and how they can be used to attack the root cause of T2D, metabolic syndrome, and obesity.

title: Insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, and the overflow paradigm
content: Insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, and the overflow paradigm. How hyperinsulinemia drives metabolic syndrome. Insulin and weight gain, and using fasting to empty the cells of glucose.

title: Reducing proliferation with rapamycin, nutrition, exercise, fasting, and manipulating hormones

title: Does fasting cause gallstones?

title: Evidence-Based Medicine and Infectious Disease
content: Best example of evidence-based medicine working: infectious disease. The treatment most infections is remarkable (e.g., HIV). Infections are quite acute, very easy and binary to measure progression. The interventions are simple (i.e., take this medication/don’t take this medication). You get the answer if it’s working really quickly (looking at T-cell count or amelioration).

title: Risk of Inaction in Type II Diabetes
content: People are very quick to say, “Well, you don’t have the evidence to support fasting for a patient with Type II Diabetes.” But… what’s the risk of NOT doing something? You must compare the risk of doing something with the risk of NOT doing something. For example, people with Type 2 diabetes risk of NOT doing anything: Continue to get treated with more and more insulin to control blood glucose. It’s a virtual certainty that they will eventually have to go on dialysis. So the risk of doing nothing is huge compared to the risk of an intervention like fasting.

title: Nephrology and Kidney Disease
content: Nephrology is a specialty of medicine that concerns itself with the kidneys: the study of normal kidney function and kidney disease, the preservation of kidney health, and the treatment of kidney disease, from diet and medication to renal replacement therapy (dialysis and kidney transplantation). With kidney disease, there are two general treatments: Prednisone and Dialysis.

title: Kidney as an Early Warning Indicator
content: The kidney as an early warning indicator of high blood pressure and high glucose. The eyes are generally the first place you can see disease. Second place is probably the kidneys by looking at urine (which is formed in the kidney). About 20% of the entire blood circulation of the body passes through the kidney… and most of it passes through the glomerulus (“the functional unit of the kidney”).

title: Correlation to Heart Disease
content: Increased urine albumin excretion has a very, very strong correlation to heart disease. Not because having albumin in the urine is so bad, but it tells you that there’s something bad going on in the blood vessels of the kidney. Which therefore tells you something bad is going on in the blood vessels of the body.

title: Insulin Resistance, Hyperinsulinemia, and the Overflow Paradigm
content: The problem is not insulin resistance per se, the problem is hyperinsulinemia. Using insulin to push more and more glucose into the cells is a problem because the cell is already too full in a person with insulin resistance/T2D. The solution is to empty that cell of glucose… that’s the whole solution. But that is a totally different paradigm than what we’ve been taught… we use sulfonylureas and exogenous insulin trying to shove more glucose into this already filled cell.

title: Common Treatments for Type 2 Diabetes
content: The majority of drugs to treat T2D aren’t actually aimed at decreasing glucose, it’s more about increasing insulin, such as Sulfonylureas, Exogenous insulin, DPP-4 inhibitors. These drugs are similar to your wife screaming at you to put more shirts in. At first, you can do it, but as you keep doing that, the problem just keeps getting worse and worse. At first it’s a little full, and then it’s a lot too full.

title: Insulin and Glucose Control
content: Putting more glucose into the liver, which is what insulin does, instead of taking all that glucose out of the liver can lead to health issues. Tight control of glucose with insulin doesn’t work long term. It’s not the blood glucose per se, it’s the whole-body glucose. If you take the glucose that’s in the blood and simply shove it into the liver, you’re just covering up the problem. It’s the whole-body glucose moving the glucose from one compartment of the body, which is the blood, to another compartment, which is the liver.

title: SGLT2 Inhibitors and Their Effects
content: The SGLT2s are a new class of drug which blocks the receptor on the kidneys where you’re actually absorbing the glucose, and you actually pee out the sugar. Side effects include urine infections, yeast infections, and ketoacidosis. However, trials show that they have a huge protective effects against kidney disease, reducing the risk by about 25% and also reducing the risk of heart disease.

title: Exercise and Glucose Uptake
content: Exercise increases a reservoir for glucose uptake, the muscle. The more one exercises, the more he/she could put away glucose into a muscle as glycogen. However, it is much less efficient than attacking the diet. The liver is really the key to type 2 diabetes, and you can’t exercise the liver.

title: Metabolic Syndrome and Insulin
content: Metabolic syndrome which is a constellation of five things: Increased blood glucose, Abdominal obesity, High triglycerides, Low HDL, High blood pressure. The liver has too much glucose because of too much insulin so the liver is jam-packed. It wants to get rid of all this extra fat so it’s putting out tons of triglycerides (you get hypertriglyceridemia). And as triglycerides go up, HDL goes down. As you’re exporting out all of this fat, this fat goes into all kinds of places where it’s not supposed to go (the pancreas, the omentum fat, etc.) and you get abdominal obesity.

title: Insulin and Weight Gain
content: Studies show that insulin causes weight gain. People gained weight and eventually became hyperinsulinemic. Even T1D patients became hyperinsulinemic. You start out taking 15 units a day when you’re a kid and then by the time you’re 45, you’re taking like 60 units a day. Why? You developed insulin resistance, and yet you had no insulin in your body in the first place 20 years ago.

title: Fasting to Empty the Cells of Glucose
content: There is no more potent way to lower insulin than to fast. By eating nothing you are going to force your body to start using another fuel, and the first place it’s going to pull it out of is this fatty liver.

title: Developing Type 2 Diabetes
content: The two-step process of developing type 2 diabetes is first insulin resistance (or said a better way: hyperinsulinemia) and next, Pancreas atrophies after spending so much effort to produce more and more insulin and it finally fails (beta-cell failure). After the beta-cell failure is when the blood glucose go way up. This process takes about 10 years.

title: NAFLD and Hyperinsulinemia
content: A very common patient presentation is the following: Hyperinsulinemia, with or without normal glucose levels. Hemoglobin A1c is often completely normal. Their ALT is high, much higher than we would like to see, though not so high that people would get alarmed by it. And if you could get an ultrasound of the liver and you would almost assuredly see the accumulation of fat. And a treatment plan for that patient will resolve the NAFLD, normalize the ALT, and reduce hyperinsulinemia.

title: Fructose Metabolism and Insulin Resistance
content: The fructose, which is metabolized in the liver, is causing fat accumulation specifically in the liver, and that is going to cause hyperinsulinemia, because the liver is full of all this excess fat, now you’re trying to shove all this glucose into this fatty liver cell and the liver is like, “no, I can’t take anymore so I’m going to be resistant to this”. And as the liver gets resistant, the blood glucose goes up and then the body starts to have to make more insulin to control that situation.

title: Obesity and Insulin Resistance as Protective Mechanisms
content: Obesity, insulin resistance, and fatty pancreas are not actually detrimental, they’re actually protective. For example, obesity is a response to too much glucose. The body stops taking in glucose, which is insulin resistance, to protect itself from the effects of too much glucose. The same goes for fatty liver. The body is actually trying to protect itself against the root cause of the problem which is too much insulin, too much glucose.

title: Treatment with Insulin and Weight Gain
content: When you actually give people more insulin, you actually keep all that glucose inside. And guess what? They gain weight.

title: Role of Inflammation in Obesity
content: The other thing that seems to go hand in hand with hyperinsulinemia in patients is they also tend to be quite inflamed (measured via C-reactive protein, fibrinogen, interleukins, cardiac specific forms of inflammation, etc.). However, anti-inflammatory medicine doesn’t seem to help people lose weight consistently.

title: CVD and Cancer: Diseases of too much growth
content: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) and cancer, the two top killers in America, are both diseases of too much growth. Growth in adults is generally bad. Once you reach adult size, your liver doesn’t grow, your kidney doesn’t grow, you shouldn’t be growing. Obesity, fatty liver, these are diseases of excess growth.

title: Reducing Proliferation with Rapamycin, Nutrition, Exercise, Fasting, and Manipulating Hormones
content: Rapamycin has antiproliferative properties. Every chronic disease is some amount of hyperproliferation/hyper-growth. Nutrition is one tool, exercise is another, and the use of hormones themselves (in cases where there’s deficiencies) being another tool.

title: Chronic Disease Treatment
content: Today, we are treating mostly chronic diseases. We shifted from treating infectious diseases to chronic diseases but we never changed our paradigm of medicine. As a doctor, I give you a pill, an antibiotic, and you get better. Then people came in with diseases like diabetes and obesity and the related diseases of too much growth (cardiovascular disease and cancer) and we basically said 'let me give you a pill'. That’s totally the wrong thing because you don’t have a pill to decrease proliferation.

title: Nutrient Sensing Pathways
content: The three nutrient sensing pathways are Insulin, mTOR, and AMPK. Insulin responds to dietary carbohydrates and dietary proteins. mTOR responds mostly to dietary protein. AMPK actually measures the ATP, the AMPA, ATP ratio … so it actually doesn’t care what you eat, it just cares about the cellular energy availability.

title: Benefits of Fasting
content: Intermittent fasting decreases your insulin, decreases your mTOR, and increases your AMPK. All three things that you need to do in order to decrease proliferation so it’s the 'best bang for your buck'. Fasting every so often has incredible benefits because you’re going to be able to affect those diseases of excessive growth.

title: Implementing Fasting in Practice
content: Before starting on longer fasts, patients are first started with time-restricted feeding and dietary restriction. Depending on how well those 2 approaches work, patients may begin to incorporate longer fasting. Fasting is easier for patients. When patients started seeing really good results, it was clear that this approach was effective.

title: Bariatric Surgery vs Fasting
content: Bariatric surgery is a surgical procedure where the part of the bowel that comes out of the stomach is cut and reattached. This procedure can lead to significant changes in the nutrition of the patient. However, fasting can achieve similar results without surgery. Fasting can reverse T2D because it drops insulin levels very low and forces the body to metabolize fat for energy.

title: Misconceptions about Fasting
content: Most people don’t fast not because they can’t do it, but because people are telling them they shouldn’t fast. Nutritional epidemiology studies are often misleading and results from these studies are a correlation, not causation.

title: Time-restricted Feeding and Intermittent Fasting
content: A 16 hour fast with an 8 hour feeding window (16:8) is a common time-restricted feeding protocol. This approach is more practical than counting carbs or calories. Intermittent fasting is when you periodically fast for more than 24 hours. This can be a complete reduction of calories or a hypo-caloric fast.

title: Fasting Case Study
content: A 40 year old patient with a non-healing diabetic foot ulcer was told, 'Your problem is not your foot. Your problem is your diabetes, because the reason you have this foot ulcer is because of diabetes.'

title: Fasting and Health
content: A full week of fasting followed by a 36 hour fast 3 times per week can lead to significant health improvements. This approach can be particularly beneficial for individuals with severe health conditions. However, it's important to note that every patient is different and people respond differently to fasting. It's crucial to manage expectations and prepare individuals for potential symptoms such as difficulty sleeping, headaches, cramps, diarrhea, and hunger. It's also important to ensure they understand it is temporary pain for powerful results.

title: Supportive Environment for Fasting
content: A supportive environment is key for successful fasting. This includes a family and environment that supports the individual, setting expectations regarding symptoms, and making sure they understand it is temporary pain for powerful results. Creating a supportive community that’s going to help your success is also beneficial.

title: Managing Electrolytes During Fasting
content: During fasting, it's important to manage electrolytes. Sodium and magnesium levels can be affected during fasting. Sodium depletion can occur, but if you’re otherwise healthy, your kidneys should be able to reabsorb all the sodium it needs. Magnesium depletion is more common, especially in type two diabetics, and magnesium supplements are often recommended. For dizziness, bone broth, which contains calories and amino acids, can help.

title: Managing Hunger During Fasting
content: Feeling hunger is normal during fasting, but it's important to ensure you aren’t extraordinarily lethargic. Even seasoned fasters still get hungry, but it’s never a feeling of hunger that is more profound than a regular day feeling “really hungry”. It’s the anticipation of the hunger that becomes problematic.

title: Muscle Loss During Fasting
content: During fasting, there is a period of gluconeogenesis where protein is broken down. However, this is often confused and called muscle loss. It's important to note that the body should store food energy as glycogen and body fat, but the minute you need to use it, you start burning muscle.

title: Fasting for Longevity
content: Fasting can benefit a healthy person in terms of reducing the odds of chronic disease down the line. If you use fasting to drop your insulin levels every so often, you’re going to lower your chance of getting diseases of hyperinsulinemia (heart disease, stroke, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, type two diabetes, obesity).

title: Fasting and Gallstones
content: There is weak epidemiology suggesting that skipping breakfast will increase your risk of gallstones. However, many people have gallstones, but there doesn't seem to be an increased risk with fasting. The problem is that people who follow a low fat diet seem to run into issues. Your gallbladder uses bile to emulsify fats. Therefore when there’s not fat in your diet the bile just sits around with all this stuff and you get sludge. Then, you start eating a higher fat diet and you are then squeezing it out and you’re getting stones.
